issue.title: Create a line length test helper
issue.body:
A line length test helper will take a chunk of source , and a regex, and verify the bear accepts source under the line length and rejects lines over the line length.
The max_line_length setting can be automatically determined by the lines in the source provided by the caller.  The bear should pass this test.
The regex is then used to increase the size of the source line lengths by 1 character, in accordance with the source language rules.
The helper confirms that the source was increased by 1 character only, and re-runs the bear, and expects it to fail.

issue.title: Support Python 3.4.x
issue.body:
Python 3.4.0-3 were dropped because of 8a08cd2, due to Python <3.4.4 not having asyncio.run_coroutine_threadsafe.  This has only happened in the current dev release.
However package trollius provides that on Python 2.7+
Python 3.4.3 is used as the Trusty default, so supporting it has benefit to users and especially to CI which uses that by default for all non-Python languages.
It also means the platform requirements of 0.11 will continue to be supported by the next release.

issue.title: Describing languages which enclose another language
issue.body:
Related to #1690 , we can start by describing languages which enclose other languages, in our language definitions at coalib/bearlib/languages/definitions/ .
Sometimes the enclosing language supports any language inside it, such as markdown and rst allowing "code blocks" which the user determining the language of the code block, and the identifiers used being unrestricted and the contents being largely ignored.  This issue doesnt intend to help with those cases.
However other enclosing languages only allow specific languages to be nested inside them.
Examples:

Literate Haskell allows Haskell inside.
PHP allows HTML inside.
Visual Basic allows XML inside (#5587)

We need to expand the language definition class to describe these relationships between outer and inner languages.

issue.title: Make the README a kinder place by removing/replacing the John Woods quote
issue.body:
This is migrated from #5767
As @joenash suggests,
Hey folks ðŸ‘‹

This PR is to discuss the removal of the John Woods quote from the README. I believe that quote is a product of its time (1991), and that Coala can do better to be a welcoming project.
We should write maintainable code because we have respect for our peers and colleagues who will read and work with it, not because of threat of death. The quote is also unnecessarily gendered.

Apologies also for the drive-by PR ðŸ™‡ For some additional context, I became aware of this quote because I work with a lot of software development students, and saw a large number were contributors to Coala. Coala is doing an amazing job of being accessible to students and upcoming software developers, but this also makes it important to ensure that students who work on this project are being taught respect for their fellow humans ðŸ’–

I've added [WIP] as currently this commit removes the quote entirely. It may be more suitable to find an alternative to fill that space and act as the one-line pitch. If anyone has suggestions, please feel free to add them!

Some follow-up discussions can be found on that PR. This issue is opened as the pull request is not a correct place to discuss/vote.

issue.title: FileDict and FileProxy fixes
issue.body:
fbe8452 introduced FileDict, as a subclass of dict.
It contains many unnecessary methods which needlessly override the dict method.  The override methods mostly just call the super() method, creating an extra performance degradation.
The only method which isnt just super() is __getitem__.  It contains a bug, because if the value in the dict has 0 lines, val is [] , and if val: will be false, and None is returned instead of [].  That is wildly different behaviour to previously, as None is not iterable.  It means all code (including global bears) needs to check whether the file is None before iterating over the file contents.  File contents being None was previously possible, but only when 'raw' mode was enabled.  A file with 0 lines is not the same as an unreadable / raw file.
FileFactory was introduced in b06dfe4.  The most critical problem is that it is not a "factory".  Factories are an extremely important and very well established pattern covered in all OO books with buying ( https://www.oodesign.com/factory-pattern.html ), so to call this a factory is very confusing / misleading.
It was to be a wrapper for a "file" object, which was previously a list of str, where each item was a line of the file.  While a design goal was to hide some of the details, it still needs to be backwards compatible in order to avoid breaking existing code.  This is especially important at the moment given that the current status of coala is so bug ridden with many regressions that investigating bugs requires installing from old git commits more than a year to verify the old behaviour.
Two "list" unimplemented methods which were used by coala-quickstart are __len__ and __getitem__.  These missing methods need to be re-implemented.  If there is a good justification for deprecating them, that deprecation should be done properly.  For __len__, it seems unjustifiable to not provide this, as this single number can be cached and provides a lot of information, and is especially helpful if avoiding re-reading files which have been evicted from the cache, as a 0 line file can be more efficiently created in memory than re-reading from the disk.  __getitem__ is much easier to justify deprecating if the file contents are being evicted from the cache to reduce the memory footprint of coala.  That hasnt been implemented yet.

issue.title: LocalBearTestHelper: Proper deprecation for timeout
issue.body:
#5723 was an over-hasty way of removing the dependency on pytest.
The assert not timeout broke one of the bears which used the timeout.
The bear was updated to remove the unnecessary timeout, but the assert will break old versions of coala-bears being used with the current coalib, which needlessly complicates setting up an environment to investigate old bugs.
It should be properly deprecated with a warning that the timeout is ignored.

issue.title: Running Coala when a PR is created
issue.body:
Hello,
I'm currently using Coala manually but I think it could be a nice improvement if Coala could be run when a PR is sent to a repository.
With Julia language, there is a nice Github bot called FemtoCleaner which is able to fix automatically depreciation warnings and send PR automatically to Github repositories where this bot is installed.
A similar feature for Python and linting / fixing code with Coala could be a nice improvement.
I also wonder if Github Actions https://github.com/features/actions https://www.techworm.net/programming/github-actions-workflow-automating-tool/  couldn't also be used (when available) to provide a nice workflow for linting / fixing code with Coala.
Kind regards

The persistent_hash test failing could be nearly treated as "expected". Pickle data and thus hash representation might change for different Python versions. From usability perspective this is not a problem, but we would have to rethink how to write tests for persistent_hash. But since this might be flaky as well as this issue, I would raise a bug only when we really face it on our CI for master / we are finally going to test on Python 3.7.

pip3 install -r requirements.txt -r test-requirements.txt
# Test step
pytest -k core

issue.title: XML literals
issue.body:
Visual Basic (and probably other .Net-ish languages) have XML literals.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/visual-basic/programming-guide/language-features/xml/xml-literals-overview
We might consider them to be a string with nested delimiters (#5573) , but they are more than that.
We at the very least need to delineate text within XML elements (CDATA) as strings, so that they are not seen as code.

issue.title: LocalBearTestHelper.assertComparableObjectsEqual doesn't give any helpful details when the attribute variable is a dict containing a class
issue.body:
When I was trying to solve coala/coala-bears#2571 , I made a mistake in Result.from_values()'s diffs argument which is a dict with {filename: Diff()} structure, which was intended for the "expected value". Precisely, I made a mistake (I put a wrong argument) when creating the Diff instance that I need to put in the diffs argument. But when I ran the test, I got an error result like this:
E               AssertionError: {'short_url_redirect_text': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f6341d2edd8>} != {'short_url_redirect_text': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f6341d964e0>}
E               - {'short_url_redirect_text': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f6341d2edd8>}
E               ?                                                                          ^ ^^^
E               
E               + {'short_url_redirect_text': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f6341d964e0>}
E               ?                                                                          ^^^ ^
E                : diffs mismatch.

../coala/coalib/testing/LocalBearTestHelper.py:132: AssertionError

From that AssertionError log, I thought LocalBearTestHelper.assertComparableObjectsEqual() also matches the memory id, but actually it's not.
I hope I can also get the elements that differ inside of the Diff class which is contained in a dict in a class attribute

issue.title: Add linter option to remove an error message if line/column number is 0
issue.body:
For example, CheckStyle may report an error as follows:
CheckstyleBad.java:0: Missing package-info.java file
Line number 0 means it is unrelated to any particular line, but the whole file. When coala detects 0 line/column number, it should not generate an error message. Instead, drop that error and emit a warning (after stripping that number).
ref. https://gitter.im/coala/coala-bears?at=5b3cfbf17b811a6d63cf84fe

issue.title: FileFactory: Use `cached-property` package instead of manual written `memoize_property` decorator
issue.body:
A package for exactly that exists, so we should use it. Then we can remove some code on our side.
Acceptance criteria:

FileFactory uses @cached_property from the package cached-property instead of @memoized_property for all annotated fields.
FileFactory.__init__ does not initialize self.cache = {} any more.
The file memoized_property.py is deleted.

issue.title: Travis docs cache invalidated
issue.body:
Each master travis job ends with
change detected (content changed, file is created, or file is deleted):
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.bearlib.abstractions.doctree
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.bearlib.aspects.doctree
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.bearlib.doctree
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.bearlib.languages.definitions.doctree
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.bearlib.languages.doctree
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.bearlib.languages.documentation.doctree
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.bearlib.naming_conventions.doctree
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.bearlib.spacing.doctree
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.bears.doctree
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.collecting.doctree
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.core.doctree
/home/travis/build/coala/coala/docs/_build/doctrees/coalib.doctree
...

This is happening even when the job doesnt modify the source for the docs, like
https://travis-ci.org/coala/coala/builds/401439163
One reason is these are binary files (pickles?), and they include the full path of each file, which on travis means that the masters catch entry includes /home/travis/build/coala/coala/ while the fork contains /home/travis/build/jayvdb/coala/.  As this is happening on master builds also, there is also something else in these files causing it to be invalidated.
In that directory is also a environment.pickle and index.doctree, and they are not being invalidated.
They should be cached, especially environment.pickle which is very large.

issue.title: TestUtilities.execute_coala should check for timeouts
issue.body:
If there was a timeout during a test using execute_coala, pytest-timeout will emit Failed: Timeout >35.0s (number may change) and the timeout failure will be lost inside execute_coala/bear_test_module.
The test module will continue with the assertions, and cause various errors, as these coala output will be in a strange incomplete state.
This is one of the problems affecting #5571 and #5390
A quick workaround is to detect Failed: Timeout is stderr inside execute_coala and re-raise the problem with the complete stderr and stdout for debugging purposes.

issue.title: Update the catalog of available actions when a user chains the actions together in input
issue.body:
During a coala interaction session, the acquire_actions_and_apply() function updates the catalog of actions available to the user after the successful application of each action. This way the set of actions available to the user is based on the current status of the Result object. It does so by running an is_applicable() check  for all actions.
But this happens only when a user selects actions one after the other. On the other hand if he/she chains actions together, coala just executes them one after the other without ever updating the catalog. This allows for some counter-intuitive use-cases like follows:

**** SpaceConsistencyBear [Section: cli | Severity: NORMAL] ****
!    ! Line contains following spacing inconsistencies:
!    ! - Trailing whitespaces.
[----] /home/nityeshaga/coala/coala-tutorial/src/main.c
[++++] /home/nityeshaga/coala/coala-tutorial/src/main.c
[   1] #include <stdio.h>
[   1] #include <stdio.h>
[    ] *0. Do (N)othing
[    ]  1. (O)pen file
[    ]  2. (A)pply patch
[    ]  3. Print (M)ore info
[    ]  4. Add (I)gnore comment
[    ]  5. Show Applied (P)atches
[    ]  6. (G)enerate patches
[    ] Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit): a
[    ] Patch applied successfully.
[    ] *0. Do (N)othing
[    ]  1. (O)pen file
[    ]  2. Print (M)ore info
[    ]  3. Add (I)gnore comment
[    ] Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit): g
[    ] Please enter a valid letter or number.

As we can see, normally, the user cannot select GeneratePatchesAction after selecting the ApplyPatchAction. But coala allows him/her to do so by chaining the actions together as follows --

**** SpaceConsistencyBear [Section: cli | Severity: NORMAL] ****
!    ! Line contains following spacing inconsistencies:
!    ! - Trailing whitespaces.
[----] /home/nityeshaga/coala/coala-tutorial/src/main.c
[++++] /home/nityeshaga/coala/coala-tutorial/src/main.c
[   1] #include <stdio.h>
[   1] #include <stdio.h>
[    ] *0. Do (N)othing
[    ]  1. (O)pen file
[    ]  2. (A)pply patch
[    ]  3. Print (M)ore info
[    ]  4. Add (I)gnore comment
[    ]  5. Show Applied (P)atches
[    ]  6. (G)enerate patches
[    ] Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit): ag
[    ] Patch applied successfully.
[WARNING][22:44:59] 'cli' is an internally reserved section name. It may have been generated into your coafile while running coala with --save. The settings in that section will inherit implicitly to all sections as defaults just like CLI args do. Please change the name of that section in your coafile to avoid any unexpected behavior.
[    ] *0. Do Nothing
[    ]  1. Apply patch ('SpaceConsistencyBear')
[    ]  2. Apply patch ('ArtisticStyleBear')
[    ]  3. Apply patch ('CSecurityBear')
[    ]  4. Apply patch ('ClangBear')
[    ]  5. Apply patch ('ClangComplexityBear')
[    ]  6. Apply patch ('GNUIndentBear')
[    ]  7. Apply patch ('DocGrammarBear')
[    ]  8. Apply patch ('DocumentationStyleBear')
[    ]  9. Apply patch ('FilenameBear')
[    ]  10. Apply patch ('InvalidLinkBear')
[    ]  11. Apply patch ('KeywordBear')
[    ]  12. Apply patch ('LicenseCheckBear')
[    ]  13. Apply patch ('LineCountBear')
[    ]  14. Apply patch ('LineLengthBear')
[    ]  15. Apply patch ('MementoBear')
[    ]  16. Apply patch ('SpaceConsistencyBear')
[    ]  17. Apply patch ('URLBear')
[    ]  18. Apply patch ('coalaBear')
[    ]  Enter a number:

IMHO we need a more consistent behaviour across such use-cases.

issue.title: "filters" rewrite
issue.body:
Foremost,
[['language', 'c', 'java'], ['can_fix', 'syntax']]

is just wrong on every level.
Very worst case it should be tuples, not lists.
However it should be a dict, or OrderedDict if the order matters.
{'language': ['c', 'java'], 'can_fix': 'syntax'}

And better yet it should be a proper class, so that it can be used in type annotations.
In some places this 'structure' is given argument name filters, which hints it may contain multiple items.
In other places (e.g. apply_filter) it is filter_name.
And for is_valid_filter, the arg name is filter, which is a builtin function.

issue.title: Remove implementation of SpaceConsistencyTestBear
issue.body:
SpaceConsistencyTestBear contains an old algorithm of the SpaceConsistencyBear.
And there are five tests which depend on the output of its algorithm.
When the run method is replaced with pass, these tests fail:
FAIL tests/coalaCITest.py::coalaCITest::test_limit_files_affirmative
FAIL tests/coalaCITest.py::coalaCITest::test_show_patch
FAIL tests/coalaCITest.py::coalaCITest::test_show_patch_debug
FAIL tests/coalaTest.py::coalaTest::test_run_coala_no_autoapply
FAIL tests/coalaTest.py::coalaTest::test_run_coala_no_autoapply_debug

But more importantly, some unexpected parts of the codebase suddenly have no coverage.
coalib/coala_main.py                                                  104      1     48      1    99%   207, 206->207
coalib/output/ConsoleInteraction.py                                   337      1    156      1    99%   296, 287->296
coalib/results/result_actions/ShowPatchAction.py                       72      2     28      1    97%   104-107, 103->104

That means those lines of code are being indirectly tested by the inner workings of the bear.
These lines of code all need specific tests which are not based on large, old and convoluted algorithm of a bear.
They should have tiny neat little bears which are very simple and do only enough to activate those lines of code, and do it directly.

issue.title: linter/strip_ansi: Error when using `use_stderr=True` and `use_stdout=True`
issue.body:
The feature added in #5281 has a flaw when using the options use_stderr=True and use_stdout=True together:
output = tuple(compress(
    output,
    (options['use_stdout'], options['use_stderr'])))
if len(output) == 1:
    output = output[

if options['strip_ansi']:
    output = strip_ansi(output)
In that case output becomes a tuple and strip_ansi will fail:
TypeError: expected string or bytes-like object

issue.title: process_output_corrected should not treat \n as reason to empty a file
issue.body:
If there is an error on stderr, usually stdout is \n.
process_output_corrected should not interpret \n as intended to be the corrected file being an empty file.  It should emit an INFO message to say \n was ignored.
Possibly an extra flag might be added to allow \n to really mean an empty file, if there is no way that the linter ever has an empty file except when it is recommending an empty file (but #2821 , that is almost never correct, which is why it is stupid to let empty files be created.)
c.f. coala/coala-bears#2414 (comment)
Also this will probably fix the regular problems we have with MarkdownBear.

issue.title: Identify missing CAN_FIX

issue.title: test_user_coafile_parsing doesnt use setUp and tearDown

test_user_coafile_parsing modifies Constants.user_coafile during the test.
If the assertEqual fails, Constants.user_coafile will not be restored, which could result in lots of other tests to fail in unpredictable ways.
The test class should have a setUp and tearDown which saves & restores any coalib state which is modified during the tests in that class.

issue.title: Updating dependencies doesn't flush cache
issue.body:
Overview Description
Whenever a linter is upgraded, the cache of coala is not flushed and new linting fixes introduced in the dependency are not shown
For e.g, take pycodestyle
W605 invalid escape sequence '\s' was introduced in pycodestyle==2.4
So when coala is run with pycodestyle==2.3, the output is cached and thus doesn't show any results for W605
But even after updating to pycodestyle==2.4, the output is shown exactly same as before being cached
Steps to Reproduce
Create a directory (mkdir cacheTest).
Make a file file.py having contents:
import re

reg = '#\s(\d+)'
string = '#123, # 123'

print(re.compile(reg).findall(string))

The contents of .coafile are:
[all]
files = file.py
bears = PycodestyleBear


Ensure pycodestyle is set to version 2.3

pip install pycodestyle==2.3


Run coala

coala


Now install pycodestyle version 2.4

pip install pycodestyle==2.4


Now again run coala

coala

5 Now run coala with flushed cache
coala --flush-cache

Actual Results
The output is different after flushing the cache
Expected Results
After updating to pycodestyle==2.4, there shouldn't have been a need to explicitly flush cache
Reproducibility
100%
Additional Information:
A sample run on my machine:
(coala) viresh@viresh-PC:~/Desktop/coalaDebug$ pip install pycodestyle==2.3
Collecting pycodestyle==2.3
  Using cached https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/32/09/8e580517e4af96141c41f531bca14c4408e7cb716864022737811aaac1be/pycodestyle-2.3.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Installing collected packages: pycodestyle
  Found existing installation: pycodestyle 2.4.0
    Uninstalling pycodestyle-2.4.0:
      Successfully uninstalled pycodestyle-2.4.0
Successfully installed pycodestyle-2.3.0
You are using pip version 9.0.1, however version 10.0.1 is available.
You should consider upgrading via the 'pip install --upgrade pip' command.


(coala) viresh@viresh-PC:~/Desktop/coalaDebug$ coala
Executing section all...
Executing section cli...


(coala) viresh@viresh-PC:~/Desktop/coalaDebug$ pip install pycodestyle==2.4
Collecting pycodestyle==2.4
  Using cached https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/e5/c6/ce130213489969aa58610042dff1d908c25c731c9575af6935c2dfad03aa/pycodestyle-2.4.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Installing collected packages: pycodestyle
  Found existing installation: pycodestyle 2.3.0
    Uninstalling pycodestyle-2.3.0:
      Successfully uninstalled pycodestyle-2.3.0
Successfully installed pycodestyle-2.4.0
You are using pip version 9.0.1, however version 10.0.1 is available.
You should consider upgrading via the 'pip install --upgrade pip' command.


(coala) viresh@viresh-PC:~/Desktop/coalaDebug$ coala
Executing section all...
Executing section cli...


(coala) viresh@viresh-PC:~/Desktop/coalaDebug$ coala --flush-cache
Executing section all...

file.py
[   3] regÂ·=Â·'#\s(\d+)'
**** PycodestyleBear (W605) [Section: all | Severity: NORMAL] ****
!    ! W605 invalid escape sequence '\s'
[    ] *0. Do (N)othing
[    ]  1. (O)pen file
[    ]  2. Add (I)gnore comment
[    ] Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit): 0

file.py
[   3] regÂ·=Â·'#\s(\d+)'
**** PycodestyleBear (W605) [Section: all | Severity: NORMAL] ****
!    ! W605 invalid escape sequence '\d'
[    ] *0. Do (N)othing
[    ]  1. (O)pen file
[    ]  2. Add (I)gnore comment
[    ] Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit): 0
Executing section cli...
(coala) viresh@viresh-PC:~/Desktop/coalaDebug$ 

TL;DR :
Upgrading dependencies should flush the cache. It doesnt.
Cache needs to record something about the dependencies to trigger flushing.
Possibilities: Maybe executable file timestamp Or dep management needs to obtain version of installed dep and that should be stored in coala settings cache
difficulty/high

issue.title: .coafile: ignore_length_regex field's regex seems vague
issue.body:
we should either check for


urls that are that long that if they are started from the beginning of the line and then also that are greater than 80 characters and then ignore them. Current regex being used ^.*https?:// seems wrong as anyone can write a line as long as he/she wants and then end it with something starting with https:// to bypass the line length  rule. i.e. we should force one to line break even if the line contains a url until the url is what they started with and the url is what they are ending their line with.


checking for urls can be made more advanced by using something like (http|ftp|https)://([\w_-]+(?:(?:\.[\w_-]+)+))([\w.,@?^=%&:/~+#-]*[\w@?^=%&/~+#-])?

issue.title: Ignore Bears that start with an _
issue.body:
coala should ignore bears that start with an _ , since these are not meant to be exposed to the user
e.g, the the _CommitBear is not meant to be exposed directly, it should only be inherited by a VCS Bear and then become invokable
currently if we do
 $ coala -B | grep Commit
[INFO][13:51:23] Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python3.5/lib2to3/Grammar.txt
[INFO][13:51:23] Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python3.5/lib2to3/PatternGrammar.txt
_CommitBear
GitCommitBear
HgCommitBear

The _CommitBear should not be exposed.
Also note that the file in which CommitBear is defined is not exactly _CommitBear, due to which a user cannot use bears=_CommitBear inside the .coafile
But if the user writes bears=CommitBear, then the _CommitBear is invoked.
Here's a sample output of the debug logs when one runs _CommitBear by specifying bears = CommitBear in the .coafile:
[DEBUG][13:47:42] Running bear _CommitBear...
[ERROR][13:47:42] Bear _CommitBear failed to run. Take a look at debug messages (`-V`) for further information.
[DEBUG][13:47:42] The bear _CommitBear raised an exception. If you are the author of this bear, please make sure to catch all exceptions. If not and this error annoys you, you might want to get in contact with the author of this bear.

Traceback information is provided below:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/mnt/Common/Earlier/GIT/coala/coala/coalib/bears/Bear.py", line 309, in execute
    return [] if result is None else list(result)
  File "/mnt/Common/Earlier/GIT/coala/coala-bears/bears/vcs/CommitBear.py", line 136, in run
    (stdout, stderr) = self.get_head_commit()
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable

issue.title: ShowPatchAction: Make patches better readable
issue.body:
Currently no context lines are displayed, which makes it very hard to grasp simple code relocations. E.g. coala proposed following patch (I added unified-diff-like markers because coala just colors added and deleted lines, it doesn't show + and -):
[----] /app/etc/test.json
[++++] /app/etc/test.json
[  18]+         "xray": {
[  19]+             "package": [
[  20]+                 "com.example.xray"
[  21]+             ],
[  22]+             "value": 33.33
[  23]+         },
[  23]-         },
[  24]-         "xray": {
[  25]-             "package": [
[  26]-                 "com.example.xray"
[  27]-             ],
[  28]-             "value": 33.33

I just relocated the xray entry, but it's really hard to see that (look at the line numbers). Esp. you have a problem to check where it is exactly located. You can only see the line numbers, open your editor, navigate to those lines, and check up if the position is correct and doesn't produce invalid JSON.
This is not acceptable and coala has to print better diffs here showing a few context lines like git does.

issue.title: Fail when a File isn't found or when a bear declared doesn't exist
issue.body:
I think coala should fail when a file isn't found or when a blob results in no files and when bear declared doesn't actually exist.
By making it into a warning, It could accidentally mistaken to be a "success" when it should actually fail. There's no good reason why it shouldn't fail, if there is when can easily solve this by adding an option in the section like allow_invalid_blobs and allow_invalid_bears.

issue.title: Exception while using variable as value for message_arguments dictionary items
issue.body:
Overview Description : When passing a variable name as a dictionary item value in message_arguments for new_result() API, it  raises an exception TypeError: unorderable types: dict() < dict().
class Rule8:
    CLASS_NAME_LOWER_CASE = {
        'message': "Class-name starts with an lower case '{name}'",
        'additional_info': "Class-name should NOT start with lower case",
        'severity': SEV.MAJOR,
        'confidence': 100
    }
for cname in cname_list: 
    yield self.new_result(**Rule8.CLASS_NAME_LOWER_CASE,
                                  message_arguments= {'name': cname},
                                  file=filename)

cname is of type <class 'str'>

Iterating through each items in cname_list and calling yield new_result with message_argument = {'name': cname}

raises an exception TypeError: unorderable types: dict() < dict().

coala should show the result.

issue.title: Change `preferred_quotation` taste's default to `"`
issue.body:
preferred_quotation taste of the Quotation aspect should default to " instead of '.
There are mainly two reasons for this.
Firstly, plenty of languages support either " or both " and '. It is worth noting that during the implementation of the bear, for languages like cpp, if preferred_quotes = ', then also, it makes sense to apply the default value (which would be " now) rather than explicitly setting it to ". Discussion is going on here coala/cEPs#148 (comment).
Secondly, the bear setting corresponding to the taste (https://github.com/coala/coala-bears/blob/master/bears/general/QuotesBear.py#L66) uses " as default value. Turning the taste to the same default will ensure consistency and less confusion while implementation and maintenance of the code.
Also, the taste may be amended for furthermore clarity as done in the cEP PR coala/cEPs#148.

issue.title: Create a mapping function when data-types differ in bear settings and it's corresponding aspect
issue.body:
There is a need for a mapping function to map bear settings to aspect tastes in cases when data types or just values differ.
e.g. use_spaces is a bear setting which takes in bool as an argument whereas it's corresponding taste indent_type takes in space or tab i.e. a string as an argument. The setting is used in approx. 15 bears, so it is worth implementing rather than handling it in all bears separately. The function will also be helpful for such instances in future when data-types differ or even when just the values differ.

issue.title: Doctests interfering with the Root aspect
issue.body:
Formatting aspect in the doctest (https://github.com/coala/coala/blob/master/coalib/bearlib/aspects/root.py#L18) overrides the actual Formatting aspect (https://github.com/coala/coala/blob/master/coalib/bearlib/aspects/Formatting.py#L5).
The problem was found here https://gitter.im/coala/coala?at=5b14d874e26c847ac8b5855d when Root.Spacing.Indentation was returning AspectNotFound error when it actually existed. The error goes and tests pass when the Formatting aspect of the doctests is renamed or doctests are disabled for pytest.
Potential solutions to this bug are explained here #5492 (comment)

issue.title: aspects: Create `allowed_values` and remove `suggested_values`
issue.body:
suggested_values is not useful as most of the times they include things like (True, False) which is but obvious when it's a bool and things like (12,34,56) when it's an int.
But yes we have indent_type which has (space, tab) in suggested_values and (", \') in preferred_quotes, these might be useful. So basically suggested_values are useful in cases when it lists us the allowed options only. Suggested values in tastes like indent_type and preferred_quotes and other such cases can be changed to allowed_values while the suggested_values can be removed from all other tastes. This won't cause any harm as suggested_values are not being used by the aspects module atm.

    :param command: The command to run on shell. This parameter can either

issue.title: Expand ruby language definition
issue.body:
The ruby language definition in coala is empty.
coala should have at least a basic language file for ruby.
There are quite a few concepts in Ruby which can not be correctly described using the limited coala language concepts, especially % string literals and balanced delimiters.

issue.title: Balanced string delimiters
issue.body:
The coala language definitions have a string_delimiters which contains pairs of (start, end), and is used for pairs where the first unescaped end is the delimiter.
It is worth noting that at the moment, escaping is hard-wired to assume \ is the escape character.
This is defined inside coala_utils's position_is_escaped.  I've raised https://gitlab.com/coala/coala-utils/issues/64 about fixing that.
Many languages have a concept of balanced string delimiters, where the delimiter is not the first unescaped end: instead it is the matching unescaped end.  A stack is required to handle this, and coala_utils's StringProcessing doesnt support this yet.
For a simple example, the curly braces in Tcl are nested string delimiters.
Ruby has % string literals which are the same concept with a leading token.
The existing coala language definition property string_delimiters can not be re-used as-is to describe these balanced string delimiters, and we couldnt possibly use it at the moment as StringProcessing doesnt support this anyway.
However it is worthwhile investigating how we might describe balanced/nested string delimiters, before attempting to implement them.
We might be able to re-use string_delimiters if we infer that any start, end which is also in encapsulators is a nested/balanced string delimiter.
That provides a way to support Tcl's {..}, but doesnt support Ruby's approach.
More analysis needed.
Quite possibly a few additional language properties will be needed to be able to correctly describe balanced string delimiters for the major languages.

issue.title: Create 'unsupported' language definitions for languages which do not use `\` as escape sequence
issue.body:
https://gitlab.com/coala/coala-utils/issues/64 shows that escape char \ is hard-wired into many functions and can not be easily removed.
To prevent bugs, we need coalang files for languages which do not use \ as the escape character, and those files need to clearly indicate that the language is not supported, with a comment explaining why.

issue.title: In `ask_for_action_and_apply()`, if `apply_single` is non-False, function should return when match is found
issue.body:
In the function ask_for_action_and_apply() in ConsoleInteraction.py, if the apply_single parameter is non-False, then the for loop inside it iterates through the entire metadata_list before returning False.
IMHO we should include a break statement inside the if block (which is in the for loop) such that the function may return after a match is found because there is no need to go through the remaining actions in metadata_list.

issue.title: Redefinition of the same function `format_lines()` in 3 files
issue.body:
The function format_lines() is defined in the exact same way in ShowAppliedPatchesAction.py, ConsoleInteraction.py and coala_main.py. (in ShowAppliedPatchesAction.py version, there is a very minor difference- the amount of padding is 4 in it whereas others contain 5, but IMHO it is inconsequential).
We should keep only one copy, I suggest the coala_main() one because:

it is "coala_main"
it contains a some comment- # type: (object, object, object) -> object

We can then import the function from coala_main() in the other 2 files. This reduces redundancy of code.

issue.title: The check at line 680 in `choose_action()` is inadequate
issue.body:
In function choose_action() in file ConsoleInteraction.py the condition

if actions_desc_len == len(actions_desc):

at line 680 informs the user of a wrong choice only if it is the only character input by him/her. If a wrong choice is entered along with a few valid ones, it fails to inform the user about it.
For example:
[    ] *0. Do (N)othing
[    ]  1. (O)pen file
[    ]  2. (A)pply patch
[    ]  3. Print (M)ore info
[    ]  4. Add (I)gnore comment
[    ]  5. Show Applied (P)atches
[    ]  6. (G)enerate patches
[    ] Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit):

If the user presses MXG (X being the invalid choice), coala fails to inform the user of a wrong character entered. It just silently executes the actions related to M and G.
Instead if the user presses just X, coala complains saying Please enter a valid letter.

issue.title: Enhance the error message when user enters an invalid choice
issue.body:
As discussed in #5214, I propose to do the following changes to the error message:

use !  ! instead of [  ] for the error message
make the message of a different colour
maybe we can show the erroneous character, that was entered, in the error message. So, it might look something like this:

!  ! (X) is not a valid letter.

This should make the error message more conspicuous and helpful.

issue.title: CachinUtilities.py: Use cPickle instead of pickle
issue.body:
In the file coalib/misc/CachingUtilities.py replace pickle with cPickle which can lead to a minor performance gain since cPickle is about 1000 times faster than pickle. We only using pickle.dump() and pickle.load() so it shouldn't have any compatibility issues since both the modules have identical functions for dumping and loading.
I'm opening this issue with reference to the optimize caching GSoC project. Even though it is a minor change it is a performance improvement nevertheless.
IMO it should remain blocked since its related to a GSoC project.
status/blocked difficulty/low type/performance

issue.body:
When the DIFF_EXCERPT_MAX_SIZE is greater than 4, then both Show Patch and Show Applied Patches is shown. The output shown by both is almost the same.
scibase-ieee-V3.py

issue.title: Vi is not added to the list of editors
issue.body:
Coala does not recognise vi as an editor, although it does recognise vim and nvim.
Vi needs to be added to the list of editors in OpenEditorAction.py
This is what happens when you try to open a file with vi:
Please enter a value for the parameter 'editor' (The editor to open the file with.): vi

choose vi editor

The editor "vi" is unknown to coala. Files won't be opened at the correct positions and other quirks might occur. Consider opening an issue at https://github.com/coala/coala/issues so we can add support for this editor. Supported editors are: atom, emacs, emacsclient, geany, gedit, gvim, kate, nano, nvim, subl, vim, xed

issue.title: No need for SpaceConsistencyBear to run if PEP8Bear is also passed into the bears argument
issue.body:
PEP8Bear also takes into consideration of Trailing Whitespaces just as SpaceConsistencyBear does. So it automatically fixes the patch. And because of that when SpaceConsistencyBear starts running from the process queue it does show that there are errors, but shows no option for the user to Apply a Patch since that patch was already applied by the PEP8Bear. This might create confusion among the users.
And IMO fixing this might also increase the performance of coala .
The Sample outputs  when both SpaceConsistencyBear and PEP8Bear are used:-
test.py
[   3] defÂ·test(a1,b1="",c1="",a2):Â·
**** PEP8Bear [Section: cli | Severity: NORMAL] ****
!    ! The code does not comply to PEP8.
[----] /home/theprophet/test-coala/test.py
[++++] /home/theprophet/test-coala/test.py
[   3] def test(a1,b1="",c1="",a2): 
[   3] def test(a1, b1="", c1="", a2):
[    ] *0. Do (N)othing
[    ]  1. (O)pen file
[    ]  2. (A)pply patch
[    ]  3. Add (I)gnore comment
[    ]  4. Show Applied (P)atches
[    ]  5. (G)enerate patches
[    ] Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit): 2
[    ] Patch applied successfully.
[    ] *0. Do (N)othing
[    ]  1. (O)pen file
[    ]  2. Add (I)gnore comment
[    ] Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit): 0

test.py
[   3] defÂ·test(a1,b1="",c1="",a2):Â·
**** SpaceConsistencyBear [Section: cli | Severity: NORMAL] ****
!    ! Line contains following spacing inconsistencies:
!    ! - Trailing whitespaces.
[    ] *0. Do (N)othing
[    ]  1. (O)pen file
[    ]  2. Print (M)ore info
[    ]  3. Add (I)gnore comment
[    ] Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit): 0

The Trailing whitespaces was already fixed by the PEP8Bear, but this issue comes up again in SpaceConsistencyBear again but now with no options to apply,since it was already fixed. IMO there is no need for the SpaceConsistencyBear to run here. It simply slows down the coala and creates confusion.

issue.title: Nextgen-Core: Raise exception in core.run() when bear or result-callback raised an exception
issue.body:
Currently the core properly cleans up the failing bear and discards all dependent tasks and bears, and then swallows the exception.
However, coala (and other users) needs to know that something didn't work perfectly, for example returning an error code that some analysis was run, but couldn't complete due to errors.
I propose to write a custom exception that aggregates all those swallowed exceptions and is then raised in core.run().
class Exceptions(Exception):
    def __init__(self, exceptions):
        super().__init__('Multiple exceptions happened:\n' + '\n\n'.join(str(ex) for ex in exceptions)
        self.exceptions = exceptions
To make use of it, the core Session has another field, e.g. self.silent_errors or self.recovered_errors (or similar), where all components can put in their errors if they can recover from them. When exiting the run, the Session checks if exceptions were placed into self.silent_errors/self.recovered_errors, constructs an Exceptions instance with all of those errors and raises it in the main thread.
Acceptance criteria:

An exception is implemented that is capable of storing multiple exceptions and emitting an appropriate error message
core.run() raises this exception if at least one bear or result-callback failed. The raised exception provides information on all exceptions occurred and swallowed inside core.run().

issue.title: Documentation: Add guidelines on how members should show their association to coala on online platforms
issue.body:
Recently I came across a GitHub profile of a guy who mentioned himself as a "Maintainer @coala"
On further investigation, I found out that he was just a member of the newcomer team and wasn't even a part of the developers team. (This has already been reported to John)
We need to lay down some ground rules for our members on how they should show their association to coala on different websites. For example:

Members of the newcomers team -> Member @coala
Members of the developers team -> Developer @coala
Members of the research team -> Research @coala

We need something along these lines so that we don't have members putting forth misleading/false information on their profiles.
cc @jayvdb

PLSQL

Swift

And many many more.
Since there are thousands of languages missing, it is suggested that contributors should create an issue only if they want to solve it.

issue.title: Run coala on specific files and use .coafile settings at the same time
issue.body:
Currently, when we want to run coala on a specific file, we may do this:
coala --bears PyLintBear --files test.py
and with --no-config flag if there is a coala configure file in the current directory (to avoid using that configuration).
However, sometimes we may want to run coala on a specific file and use settings (e.g., bears) in .coafile at the same time. (This is what https://github.com/coala/coala-vs-code is doing now).
For example, if our .coafile is as follows:
[python]
files = **.py
language = python
bears = PyLintBear

[javascript]
files = **.js
bears = JSHintBear
language = javascript
allow_unused_variables = True
javascript_strictness = False

Then if we run coala --files test.py, --files test.py is simply ignored. This is not what we expect.
Another situation is .coafile doesn't include files attribute.
For example, if our .coafile is as follows:
[python]
language = python
bears = PyLintBear

[javascript]
bears = JSHintBear
language = javascript
allow_unused_variables = True
javascript_strictness = False

Then if we run coala --files test.py, all sections would be run! Of course, we don't want to run JSHintBear on python scripts. This is also not what we expect.

What https://github.com/coala/aspect-docs does right now should be embedded as a build-step in our setup.py docs command and put into the API docs.
Then we can archive/move to GitLab/delete that repo.

issue.title: Path-settings for bears: Better support for relative files
issue.body:
From coala/coala-bears#2373 (by @cbaines):

If the rubocop config file is specified with a relative path, e.g. [1], then this means that coala must be run in a working directory such that the configuration file exists at this relative path. This breaks things like the Emacs Flycheck integration, which runs coala not always in the directory where the .coafile exists.
1:
rubocop_config = .rubocop.yml
I'm not sure if this is something that can be fixed, or how to do it. Is there someway to specifying a path in the .coafile as relative to the .coafile itself, or can the RuboCopBear determine the correct path at runtime, ... It would at least be good to have the RuboCopBear check the config file exists before trying to run rubocop.

issue.body:
The output generated by coala can have line being None or column being None.
column = None means there is an error with the whole line.
line = None means the whole file. The reason behind it is that it's an unknown line means it can occur anywhere in the file.
All combinations with None values and numbers for line and column are allowed, except line=None and column=<some number>
This should be clarified in the documentation.
(ref: http://api.coala.io/en/latest/coalib.results.html#module-coalib.results.Result)

issue.title: NextGen-Core: persistent_hash - Cache calls?
issue.body:
Using an lru_cache has the potential to speed up runs significantly that occur in the same process. This is especially useful for IDE integrations.
Evaluations have to be made implementing either Python's lru_cache with a sensible number or a different caching strategy so coala doesn't consume too many resources. A "switch" to turn on call-caching is maybe also an additional option. So a normal coala run which runs the core only once in a process has decreased memory consumption, but daemon-like applications which run coala repeatedly don't have to recompute cache-key-hashes all the time.

issue.title: Move testfixtures requirement to test-requirements.txt
NextGen-Core: Investigate usage of `attrs` package to replace/enhance `persistent_hash` for caching
issue.body:
Our requirements for a hash function:

It works on all currently existing Python objects.
It changes when the "content" of an instance changes (i.e. when fields change that identify the instance, for example a complex number: If the real or imaginary part changes, the hash needs to change too. This doesn't count for "cache" values, i.e. imagine you want to speed up repeated calls to the "abs()" function of a complex number, you have created a "_abs_cache" field which is initially None. Changing it shall not change the hash value, as it's not an "instance identifying value". If that is not avoidable, it shall be possible to override hashing behaviour in classes.)
It's not volatile across different Python runs (see for example hash randomization in Python for certain types).

There is a major problem though:

The hash function that attr generates utilizes repr. This will fulfil the above demands only for objects that are annotated with attr and only use objects annotated with it.

linter: Implement new parameters to control line-index and column-index conversion to handle zero-based and one-based conventions
issue.body:
Many tools have different conventions regarding what is the first line or column. Some emit 0, some emit 1.
Acceptance criteria:

@linter accepts argument(s) that controls the conversion of zero-based line/column indexes. When enabled, zero-based indexes are incremented by 1 to match coala's (one-based) convention. The user is able to control column- and line-conversion individually.
The new parameter is documented in our API and in our tutorials and guides (namely Writing_Linter_Bears.rst).
Tests exist for the new parameter.

Notes:
From my experience I would recommend to have only one parameter that controls the conversion for both, lines and columns at once.

API documentation: adding links to the homepage and user's guide
issue.body:
I want to propose adding the links leading to the coala homepage and the coala 'For users' guides in the navigation panel of the Coala API Documentation.
I propose this because it will make it easier to look up other information when the users are only on the API documentation page. This is mainly for the sake of new developers for reasons I will explain below. As to my knowledge, currently there isn't a way to go from the newcomer's guide to the other places directly. In my experience, I often need to look up information on the homepage or user's guide when I am completing the tasks for the new developers. For example, in step 0 -  Run Coala, I imagine many new developers would need to install Coala. Besides, new developers might want to familiarize themselves with the usage of Coala. And now if I only have the API doc page open, I would have to either google to find the other pages (or retrieve from bookmarks).
At the top of the newcomer's guide, there is already a line saying "you might also want to look at our website" with a link of the coala homepage. But I found that it feels more natural to go to the navigation panel and look for a link when you want to jump to a different page.

colorlog is pinned to 2.x. colorlog 3.0 has been released for a few months, and is now starting to cause conflicts in versions,  which causes coala to fail.

The changes in colorlog 3.0 and 3.1 do not adversely effect coala.

In any way, a concept is needed to make it work properly, also with respect to caching it has to be developed carefully (once it's being implemented).

issue.title: Helper function to compare version of installed packages.
issue.body:
We need a helper function that returns a boolean value if the user has required version of a given package.
Something like:
>version_check('libclang-py3', '3.4.0')
true

>version_check('libclang-py3', '3.2.1')
false

Use Case:
In #3847 we need to check the clang version of the user.
We can use pkg_resources to get the version of installed modules.

issue.title: change glob of ApplyPatchAction in .coafile from * to **
issue.body:
result.origin in case of many bears changes from their original name, eg. ESLintBear becomes ESLintBear (prettier/prettier) due to which the glob * may not match and ApplyPatchAction won't work.
Although it won't affect the result, but as many users often refer to this file for their own project they may find that some bears are not working if they exactly put this statement over there.
difficulty/newcomer

issue.title: Don't re.escape() cmdline path args in tests
issue.body:
2nd step after #4890 for getting rid of inconveniently used re.escape()s
Since #4883 coala cmdline args can have single-backslash path separators on Windows, which were formerly doubled in the tests by using re.escape to avoid their removal by coala's settings handling (always interpreting backslashes as escape characters)
Occurencies of those obsolete re.escape()s can be found via #5019 (comment) #5019 (comment) #5019 (comment)
Maybe there are even more... :)
cc @Makman2

issue.title: Add support for --run-after and --run-before to a particular section in coafile

.coafile
[a]
setting1...

[b]
setting2...

[c]
setting3...

[d]
setting4...

Now coala should be able to run commands
1.coala --run-after b       => coala will only execute section c and d
2.coala --run-before c    => coala will only execute section a and b

issue.title: Add support for section ordering
issue.body:
.coafile
[a]
setting1...

[b]
setting2...

[c]
setting3...

[d]
setting4...

Now, if run

coala a d c b   => should run sections in order a -> d -> c -> b
coala d c b a   => should run sections in order d -> c -> b -> a

issue.title: The glob `*` does not match all bears
issue.body:
Many bears' result.origin is not just the name of the bear. For e.g.. ESLintBear has result.origin "ESLintBear (prettier/prettier)" and the glob * doesn't match anything with file seperators in it i.e. / or \, we have to use glob **. The PR #5017 fixes the issue with --apply-patches command line argument but if the .coafile has something like this
default_actions = *: ApplyPatchAction

This may not match all bears. This needs to be solved. Many things can be done to solve this eg:


The result.origin of those bears can be changed


I don't think that any user will think this through and use glob * specifically to ignore such bears so we can internally change all the glob * to **


We can prompt the user that some bears won't if they ever use the glob *


status/needs discussion on what is the best solution

issue.body:
An earlier typo in .coafile which is being fixed by #5043 doesn't show the correct error message. Instead it shows an error based on the previous line
eg. if your .coafile has this
use_spaces = true
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

it will show
 Unable to convert parameter 'use_spaces' into type <class 'bool'>.

if your .coafile is
files = *.txt
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

It will show Unable to find that file/ No matching file
or if your .coafile is
bears = SpaceConsistencyBear
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

it will show
No bears matching 'SpaceConsistencyBear
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction' were found. Make sure you have coala-bears installed or you have typed the name correctly.

Instead it should point out the error in the statement itself

issue.title: PyUnusedCodeBear ignoring two extra lines
issue.body:
status: blocked by #4854
Steps to replicate:
take a perfect python file, and add this in the end
 # Ignore SpaceConsistencyBear, PycodestyleBear
import os as oss  
import os as sso    

print("HelloWorld")

[extra spaces after oss and sso]
use .coafile:
[cli]
bears = SpaceConsistencyBear, PycodestyleBear
use_spaces = True
files = *.py

 # Ignore SpaceConsistencyBear, PycodestyleBear
import os as oss  


import os as sso    

print("HelloWorld")

issue.title: Cache control
issue.body:
Once the NextGen-Core is implemented, we have way more possibilities for different cache operating modes that shall be available as CLI arguments in coala.


--cache-strategy / --cache-protocol:
Controls how coala manages caches for the next run.
Following modes could be implemented:

none: Don't use a cache at all. A shortcut-flag could be additionally implemented, --no-cache, effectively meaning --cache-protocol=none
primitive: Use a cache that grows infinitely. All cache entries are stored for all following runs, and aren't removed. Effective when many recurrent changes happen in coafiles and settings. Fastest in storing.
lri/last-recently-used
Cached items persist only until the next run.
Stretch issue: Implement count-parameters that allow to control when to discard items from the cache, e.g. after 3 runs of coala without using a cached item, discard it.

My recommendation is to use lri as default, as coala mostly is executed locally.


--clear-cache
Clears the cache.


--export-cache / --import-cache
Maybe useful to share caches. Like CI server for any project run coala, and you can download the cache from there as an artifact to speed up your builds / coala runs.


--cache-compression
Accepts as arguments:

none: No cache compression. This is default.
Other flags that specify common compression capabilities Python provides (for example lzma or gzip).
Cache compression should be evaluated before regarding its effectiveness, because the cache will mainly store hashes which usually aren't really redundant, the gain might be very low. The little performance penalty when loading the cache might be too much when respecting a possible very low gain of cache space reduction.



--optimize-cache
A little performance penalty to make the cache loading faster. Particularly this feature shall utilize pickletools.optimize. But this is not exclusive to this flag.

issue.title: ConfigurationGatheringTest.py add test when we are using some Local Bears and the files param is not specified
Update the Getting started tutorial by replacing the deprecated `Default` section with `cli`
issue.body:
The getting started with coala tutorial mentions the, now deprecated, Default section. Quite confusingly, it uses both cli (the correct name) and Default to refer to the same section of the .coafile at different places. This must be tripping a lot of new users.
I think that it needs a fresh rewrite in those places.
Since, this is the first entry point for new users, I feel that this should be done asap.
Related issue

issue.title: Decorator `map_setting_to_aspect` failing
issue.body:
It fail when:

Bear is decorated with it
coala running those bear without aspect mode activated

See https://ci.appveyor.com/project/coala/coala-bears/build/1.0.7521/job/ugntfdp6cxb6rt17#L930
The decorator try to search section.aspects which doesn't get instanced because coala not running in aspect mode.

issue.title: `section.aspect` attribute should have been `aspects`
issue.body: Add s.

issue.title: Change setting aspect's taste syntax
issue.body:
Currently setting an aspect's taste in coafile is using aspectname.tastename syntax. This is wrong because coala will parse it as tastename setting in aspectname section (see https://github.com/coala/coala/blob/master/coalib/parsing/LineParser.py#L32).
Change this syntax to aspectname:tastename instead.

issue.title: Test compatibility on *BSDs
issue.body:
coala currently mainly tested and known to run on Linux, macOS, and Windows. It would be a good idea to test it on *BSDs (OpenBSD, FreeBSD, NetBSD, DragonFlyBSD, etc) as well to make sure coala is compatible with them.
List of known working BSDs:

 OpenBSD 6.2 release
 OpenBSD 6.2 current
 FreeBSD 12.0 current
 FreeBSD 11.1
 NetBSD
 DragonFlyBSD ( most likely will work if it works on FreeBSD )

For those who are unfamiliar with BSD, CURRENT is the "latest bleeding edge" development branch

issue.title: Typo in Interactions.py docstring
issue.body:
In coalib/output/Interactions.py, here is the function signature and the docstring:
def fail_acquire_settings(log_printer, settings_names_dict, section):
"""
    This method throws an exception if any setting needs to be acquired.

    :param log_printer:     Printer responsible for logging the messages.
    :param settings:        A dictionary with the settings name as key and
                            a list containing a description in [0] and the
                            name of the bears who need this setting in [1]
                            and following.
"""

The settings param should be settings_names_dict to match with the function definition.

issue.title: Explain the functionality of .coafile in 'Getting Started with coala'
issue.body:
I propose that maybe we should clarify what the .coafile is for in the guide Getting Started with coala.
I am a new user of coala. I am not sure if others agree with me but I think there is one point in the 'Getting Started with coala' guide that is confusing. In the section 'Configuration Files - coafiles', the guide does not really introduce what functionality the .coafile has. It says that it is a configuration file. But what I couldn't find there is that the .coafile is something that allows you to run coala the way you want without specifying all the arguments again. Like it says in the 'about' page of the homepage, it gives one of the 2 options to run coala. I was really confused about why we need the .coafile when I was reading the guide. I have also looked into the Configuration File page in the doc to try to find out what it is. It wasn't until I stumbled upon the about section on the homepage that I see what the .coafile is for.
I have not used any tool similar to coala, so maybe this is more obvious to other people.

issue.title: Problems with nested `ignore` definitions in .coafile
issue.body:
Hi,
I have problem with ignore syntax in .coafile.
Check those 3 configurations:
# variant (1)

[all]
files = **/*.py
ignore =
    **/migrations/**,
    manage.py,
    wsgi.py,
    asgi.py,

[all.python.imports]
bears = PyImportSortBear


# variant (2)

[all]
files = **/*.py

[all.python.imports]
bears = PyImportSortBear
ignore =
    **/migrations/**,
    manage.py,
    wsgi.py,
    asgi.py,


# variant (3)

[all]
files = **/*.py
ignore =
    **/migrations/**,
    manage.py,

[all.python.imports]
bears = PyImportSortBear
ignore +=
    wsgi.py,
    asgi.py,

Variant (1) and (2) works as expected â€” files in migrations/ subdir and files wsgi.py + asgi.py are successfully ignored.
But when I try to split it like in variant (3) it doesnâ€™t work. Only wsgi.py + asgi.py are ignored, migrations/ are still checked by coala.
I also tried several variations of (3): rename section name to [all.imports], put ignore definitions on single line, include/exclude comma after last item, but all of them fails.
My env: coala version 0.11.0, run in Docker container.
Example of wrong output:
[INFO][12:40:29] Applied 'ShowPatchAction' on 'system_apps/tickets/migrations/0008_auto_20171012_1011.py' from 'PyImportSortBear'.
[INFO][12:40:29] Applied 'ShowPatchAction' on 'system_apps/tickets/migrations/0ld/0003_auto_20160913_1509.py' from 'PyImportSortBear'.

issue.title: Improve output-format system - Add export feeds
issue.body:
Currently the CLI code is generally very complicated. One part is the handling of different output formats, like JSON, formatted or normal output. Everywhere is specific code for different operation modes of coala (showing bears vs normal execution), and this will continue to become more complicated with more features we add.
Inspired by scrapy's export feeds, we can add our own ExportFeed module. This module is responsible for accepting objects from everywhere in code (e.g. with a function export, or maybe by overriding print itself) and print them accordingly to the user.
Sent objects to the export feed may be primitive (strings, ints, floats, arbitrary objects). However, to be able to control how things shall be printed/exported for different output formats, we can support overridable methods for objects, like __json__, __formatted__ or similar.
One question is maybe: Why not just letting coala return the values and we just print them?
There's a major problem with that: For example, we want to prompt results immediately in normal execution mode (checking files) as soon as they arrive. Returning results after the execution has finished is too late. So we need a system that is capable of immediately handling objects to print/export as soon as they arrive.
There are still some major points left to design (what degree of interaction shall happen in the components and in the export feed? Return values of coala command for in-Python-use or only use feed export module?), but this is a basic idea on how to possibly centralize and modularize things again.
Suggestions? :)

issue.title: Force preserve line endings when patching
issue.body:
In Windows create a python file and write the code
def a(x,y):
    pass

Change line endings to unix style.
Run coala with PEP8Bear and it will suggest you a replacement:
|   1| defÂ·a(x,y):
|   2| Â·Â·Â·Â·pass
|    | [NORMAL] PEP8Bear:
|    | The code does not comply to PEP8.
|----|    | d:\dev\ccm\source\pyccm\snmpttrules\parser.py
|    |++++| d:\dev\ccm\source\pyccm\snmpttrules\parser.py
|   1|    |-def a(x,y):
|   2|    |-    pass
|    |   1|+def a(x, y):
|    |   2|+    pass

Accept Patch.
Check line endings.
Now it's windows style line endings.
Patch should save line endings or the user should have an ability to specify which line endings style to use in the patch operation.

issue.title: Bear glob patterns are case sensitive
issue.body:
Right now, bear glob patterns in coala are case sensitive. With new options available to display bears along with its details through CLI, case sensitive is becoming hindrance in terms of usability.
For example:
coala --show-bears --bears *Clang* is giving list of bears with the word Clang in it (case sensitive)
But at the same time, coala --show-bears *clang* is failing to fetch the same list of bears.
So, if user wants to search for the details of bear(s), then (s)he must know the case of the bear which kinda doesn't make sense.

issue.title: FilterTest.test_filter_by_unknown wrongly uses assertRaisesRegex
issue.body:
FilterTest.test_filter_by_unknown executes coala in non-debug mode, checks return code, and then tries to check an exception that can never occur at that point:

  
    
      coala/tests/parsing/FilterTest.py
    
    
        Lines 101 to 110
      in
      539a4e5
    
    
    
    

        
          
           def test_filter_by_unknown(self): 
        

        
          
               with bear_test_module(): 
        

        
          
                   retval, stdout, stderr = execute_coala( 
        

        
          
                       coala.main, 'coala', '-B', '--filter-by', 'unknown', 'arg1') 
        

        
          
                   self.assertEqual(retval, 2) 
        

        
          
                   self.assertRaisesRegex(InvalidFilterException, 
        

        
          
                                          '{!r} is an invalid filter. Available ' 
        

        
          
                                          'filters: {}'.format( 
        

        
          
                                              filter, 
        

        
          
                                              ', '.join(sorted(available_filters)))) 
        
    
  


It passes anyway because assertRaisesRegex provides a context manager meant to be used via with statement. That way the whole expression is just useless. The actual error message has to be found in stdout
This blocks #4821
And BTW: There is no local filter variable defined. It just refers to the builtins.filter function ;)
cc @aashutoshrathi @shreyans800755

issue.title: Confusing bear-dependent reactions to # Ignore
issue.body:
Realized while dealing with #3337 (comment) (import at end of file, overwriting a class for experimental purpose)
For example, when there is just # Ignore at the end of the source line, PyUnusedCodeBear result for that line is not shown:
from .SimplerConfParser import SimplerConfParser as ConfParser  # Ignore
But when it's above the line, the result is shown:
# Ignore
from .SimplerConfParser import SimplerConfParser as ConfParser
**** PyUnusedCodeBear [Section: flakes | Severity: NORMAL] ****
!    ! This file contains unused source code.
[----] c:\users\zimmermann\projects\coala\lib\coalib\parsing\confparser.py
[++++] c:\users\zimmermann\projects\coala\lib\coalib\parsing\confparser.py
[ 166] from .SimplerConfParser import SimplerConfParser as ConfParser

But with full # Ignore PyUnusedCodeBear comment above the line, it works as expected:
# Ignore PyUnusedCodeBear
from .SimplerConfParser import SimplerConfParser as ConfParser
And now the strangest part! When there is an # Ignore for another bear, PyUnusedCodeBear result also isn't shown, but only if it's at end of line:

Otherwise:

issue.title: ConsoleInteractionTest.test_acquire_actions_and_apply for apply_single=True is not well designed
issue.body:
This should be processed after #4860 is merged and is will also get useful for properly testing PRs like #4179
test_acquire_actions_and_apply was just copied and only slightly modified for testing ConsoleInteraction.acquire_actions_and_apply with parameter apply_single=True:

  
    
      coala/tests/output/ConsoleInteractionTest.py
    
    
        Lines 422 to 471
      in
      8da058e
    
    
    
    

        
          
           def test_acquire_actions_and_apply(self): 
        

        
          
               with make_temp() as testfile_path: 
        

        
          
                   file_dict = {testfile_path: ['1\n', '2\n', '3\n']} 
        

        
          
                   diff = Diff(file_dict[testfile_path]) 
        

        
          
                   diff.delete_line(2) 
        

        
          
                   diff.change_line(3, '3\n', '3_changed\n') 
        

        
          
                   with simulate_console_inputs('a', 'n') as generator, \ 
        

        
          
                           retrieve_stdout() as sio: 
        

        
          
                       ApplyPatchAction.is_applicable = staticmethod( 
        

        
          
                           lambda *args: True) 
        

        
          
                       acquire_actions_and_apply(self.console_printer, 
        

        
          
                                                 Section(''), 
        

        
          
                                                 self.file_diff_dict, 
        

        
          
                                                 Result('origin', 'message', diffs={ 
        

        
          
                                                     testfile_path: diff}), 
        

        
          
                                                 file_dict, apply_single=True) 
        

        
          
                       self.assertEqual(generator.last_input, -1) 
        

        
          
                       self.assertIn('', sio.getvalue()) 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
                   class InvalidateTestAction(ResultAction): 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
                       is_applicable = staticmethod(lambda *args: True) 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
                       def apply(*args, **kwargs): 
        

        
          
                           ApplyPatchAction.is_applicable = staticmethod( 
        

        
          
                               lambda *args: 'ApplyPatchAction cannot be applied.') 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
                   old_applypatch_is_applicable = ApplyPatchAction.is_applicable 
        

        
          
                   ApplyPatchAction.is_applicable = staticmethod(lambda *args: True) 
        

        
          
                   cli_actions = [ApplyPatchAction(), InvalidateTestAction()] 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
                   with simulate_console_inputs('a') as generator, \ 
        

        
          
                           retrieve_stdout() as sio: 
        

        
          
                       acquire_actions_and_apply(self.console_printer, 
        

        
          
                                                 Section(''), 
        

        
          
                                                 self.file_diff_dict, 
        

        
          
                                                 Result('origin', 'message', 
        

        
          
                                                        diffs={testfile_path: diff}), 
        

        
          
                                                 file_dict, 
        

        
          
                                                 cli_actions=cli_actions, 
        

        
          
                                                 apply_single=True) 
        

        
          
                       self.assertEqual(generator.last_input, -1) 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
                       action_fail = 'Failed to execute the action' 
        

        
          
                       self.assertNotIn(action_fail, sio.getvalue()) 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
                       apply_path_desc = ApplyPatchAction().get_metadata().desc 
        

        
          
                       self.assertEqual(sio.getvalue().count(apply_path_desc), 0) 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
                   ApplyPatchAction.is_applicable = old_applypatch_is_applicable 
        
    
  


It keeps too much testing logic which is just completely bypassed by apply_single=True, like all those simulated console inputs and custom actions. The whole test code can be heavily reduced. And there is also a little mistake:
assertIn('', sio.getvalue()) can never fail. The empty string is always contained in any string. It should be assertNot(sio.getvalue()). There might be more such cases. I haven't looked into every detail yet...
cc @mrtes @Nosferatul @Adrianzatreanu @yukiisbored

issue.title: ConsoleInteraction.ask_for_actions_and_apply: No check for invalid apply_single
issue.body:
If apply_single refers to some non-existent action, just nothing happens. The function just returns with True:

  
    
      coala/coalib/output/ConsoleInteraction.py
    
    
        Lines 747 to 827
      in
      8da058e
    
    
    
    

        
          
           def ask_for_action_and_apply(console_printer, 
        

        
          
                                        section, 
        

        
          
                                        metadata_list, 
        

        
          
                                        action_dict, 
        

        
          
                                        failed_actions, 
        

        
          
                                        result, 
        

        
          
                                        file_diff_dict, 
        

        
          
                                        file_dict, 
        

        
          
                                        applied_actions, 
        

        
          
                                        apply_single=False): 
        

        
          
               """ 
        

        
          
               Asks the user for an action and applies it. 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
               :param console_printer: Object to print messages on the console. 
        

        
          
               :param section:         Currently active section. 
        

        
          
               :param metadata_list:   Contains metadata for all the actions. 
        

        
          
               :param action_dict:     Contains the action names as keys and their 
        

        
          
                                       references as values.
