issue.title: Setting.py: Add SourcePosition to Setting.origin
issue.body:
This adds SourcePosition to Setting.origin which helps
in identifying the starting line number of a setting in
.coafile.
Related to #5044

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText:
Rather than add a new argument, re-use origin, and let it be given either a str (filename / directory; backwards compatibility) or a SourcePosition.
There is very little use of self.origin within the class or superclasses - those uses will need to be adjusted to get the filename out of the SourcePosition when it is a filename.
The attribute Setting.origin needs to externally able to be automatically converted to a string, so str(Setting.origin) needs to work correctly.  One way to do that is for  str(SourcePosition) to be implemented.
After this initial PR, we can then also enhance ConfParser and allow Setting.origin to be given as a SourceRange to identify the precise start and end of each settings.  But that is later.  (You could do that in this PR if you wanted, but only it is easy to do.  Otherwise it is better to do this in stages.)
Then the real fun begins when we consider section inheritance and +=, and even more funky when we consider #5532 .  To model that correctly we would need a new class for "MultipleRanges", which would probably become a superclass for the Diff class which we do have.

issue.title: ConfParser.py: Support multiple +=
issue.body:
This ensures that multiple instances
of += can be used in single settings
section.
Fixes #5532

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

issue.title: Newcomers_Guide.rst: Explain newcomer issues
issue.body: (This is a bit raw and rough and aggressive.  Need help to tone it down a bit, while still being effective at being a challenge to newcomers, and adequately warning them that we dont care about their "one line change" -- it is going to be rejected if they dont comply with the guidelines.)

+The coala organisation tries to have ``newcomer`` issues always available
+for people who are joining the organisation.  These newcomer issues are
+intentionally very easy.  The only objective is to give you, the newcomer,

comments.bodyText:
This implies that people who don't follow the coala workflow are reluctant to learn ...

Correct. ;-)
We have too many drive by PRs, especially from people who attended "code sprints" or other similar workshops, who don't approach their first PR with the right mentality, and lack the self-motivation to complete it.
I hope this new blurb can shock/challenge the reader a bit, without scaring off too many.
By informing the reader in advance that a PR will not be auto-merged, it hopefully makes them more ready to see a PR as a process which might take some time, and we dont want them to start it unless they are ready to finish it.
We definitely dont want PRs from people who are not interested in learning about 'git' , etc.
Getting your first patch merged into a repository almost always requires learning, even if the change is very basic.
We should be up-front about this, not try to hide behind an overly welcoming sign on the front door, and then kick them around once they have come in the door.  The sign on the front door should say "You will get kicked around if you don't want to learn."  Nicely.

issue.title: GraphQL.py: Add language definition for GraphQL
issue.body:
Closes #5695

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText:
Yeah, so the point of aliases in this file is not to focus on the features of ANTLR's jar, the point of aliases in this file is to focus on language specific features of the grammar files, of which grun is not a part.
aliases are supposed to refer to things that mean the same as g4. For example aliases of jpeg format would be jpeg / jpg, but not Inkscape or Photoshop.
Also please not that grun is not any officially endorsed thing, it's just a bash shell alias (similar to ll which is given to org.antlr.v4.gui.TestRig for convenience sake, it could very well be any arbitrary name which we want.

issue.title: Add Brackets editor Code to known editors for coala
issue.body:
Added bracket to the list of known GUI Editors.
Guidance Required:
In order to open a file , the command goes:
Open a file in the current folder,
without switching projects:
brackets index.html
Open two files from a specific path,
without switching projects:
brackets ~/Sites/index.html ~/Sites/index.css
Open the current folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets .
Open a specific folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets ~/Sites/mysite
Brackets can be launched from the command line.
Presently it does not accept any other arguments.
Any updates required will be implemented.
Closes #5829

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText: alpha order please
@jayvdb I checked, brackets does not support jumping to a line number.
@amalrajan @utkarsh2102  thank you very much for the solution .

and the issue is still pending review , what should i do create new pull request or wait ?
@jayvdb  please guide

Never close a Pull Request. You need to learn how to fix them.
First step is to squash your 5 commits, which you can see at https://github.com/coala/coala/pull/5831/commits ,  into a single commit.
The easiest way to do that, is to delete the top 4 commits, erasing your incorrect extra commits.
To do that, you find the identifier of the first commit in your series, which was 68b6cf0 , and reset to that position.
git reset --hard 68b6cf080b
Then edit the file again, but make sure you amend your first commit, instead of creating new commits.
git add coalib/results/result_actions/OpenEditorAction.py
git commit --amend

Squash 5 commits into 1 locally and then push them to your fork,you can look onto the following link for it
https://github.com/todotxt/todo.txt-android/wiki/Squash-All-Commits-Related-to-a-Single-Issue-into-a-Single-Commit
Follow the guidelines given in https://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Writing_Good_Commits.html to write the commit message properly and you are good to go..

issue.title: docs/index.rst: Replace PNG coala header with SVG
issue.body:
The SVG of coala-header has been merged into coala/artwork
so this removes the PNG header and replace it with the SVG
and CSS. Also, the 30em width makes it responsive according
to the window size.
Closes #5592

issue.title: Add Brackets editor Code to known editors for coala
issue.body:
Added bracket to the list of known GUI Editors.
Guidance Required:
In order to open a file , the command goes:
Open a file in the current folder,
without switching projects:
brackets index.html
Open two files from a specific path,
without switching projects:
brackets ~/Sites/index.html ~/Sites/index.css
Open the current folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets .
Open a specific folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets ~/Sites/mysite
Brackets can be launched from the command line.
Presently it does not accept any other arguments.
Any updates required will be implemented.

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase

comments.bodyText:
This change wasnt fixing a bug, and he changed it to be a Closes during the code review .
See https://github.com/coala/coala/pull/5789/commits
You can still use this one here, if you use the final commit message which is Closes.
You could then mention that this is an example where the shortlog can use "fix", which isnt a "Fixes" because nothing was broken and it didnt have a bug label.  Or maybe it is too confusing ;-)
#5544 is a funny example of a Fixes .  As TrumpScript is a fictional language, it shouldnt use an file extension which is used by real language TypeScript.  It was causing real bugs.

comments.bodyText:
@AkshJain99 - Yes, i'm trying to fix it.
I don't need squashing. I need to remove some commits which is something i'm working on. Thanks for the heads up.
Just a suggestion, before pushing your code, run coala locally on it and fix the errors ðŸ˜‰

It seems there are some changes in the master branch that are conflicting with my code. I'm not sure of if I should squash the last PR into the new one or not.
The only file I was hoping to keep is this one but it seems to be saying there is a merge conflict when I keep it: 71a315d
If someone can shed some light on what might be happening, i'm all ears.

Hiya @blossomica , yes, you have a merge conflict.  Someone else has also enhanced the same section of that file, but there changes are different.
We have some git help available at https://coala.io/git , and asking for help at https://coala.io/chat will usually mean you get someone who will step you through the process of resolving a merge conflict.
Worst case, as a maintainer , I can remotely fix the merge conflict in the PR for you.  But ideally you try to solve it first.
What is not an acceptable, is starting a new Pull Request.

@jayvdb - Thanks for the clarification. It makes sense. I had no idea someone was working on the same file. But my biggest confusion (which I'll ask on gitter too) is this: when I fix the merge conflict and select "merge commit" for some reason it changes and commits more files than what I thought was changed. Like more than the file that had the merge conflict in, so I'm not sure if that is the supposed response or not, which makes me hesitant to squash that into my main commit.

@blossomica Try doing this:


Rebase the changes on your local machine which would result in some merge conflict.


Try resolving them on your local machine.


After the conflict has been resolved, try running coala locally on your machine so as to find the errors.


Once done with it, commit the changes and you are GTG


If there's an additional commit after resolving conflict, you can  squash it using git rebase -i , also known as interactive rebase.


I think this should work fine ðŸ˜„
@jayvdb  - I added the notice you suggested about the short log where fix is used but isn't an actual bug fix. So please check if that is okay too whenever you can.

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well

individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

review your PRs faster!

issue.title: Add Brackets editor Code to known editors for coala
issue.body:
Added bracket to the list of known GUI Editors.
Guidance Required:
In order to open a file , the command goes:
Open a file in the current folder,
without switching projects:
brackets index.html
Open two files from a specific path,
without switching projects:
brackets ~/Sites/index.html ~/Sites/index.css
Open the current folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets .
Open a specific folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets ~/Sites/mysite
Brackets can be launched from the command line.
Presently it does not accept any other arguments.
Any updates required will be implemented.
Closes #5829

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will

issue.title: Add Brackets Code to known editors for coala
issue.body:
Added bracket to the list of known GUI Editors.
Guidance Required:
In order to open a file , the command goes:
Open a file in the current folder,
without switching projects:
brackets index.html
Open two files from a specific path,
without switching projects:
brackets ~/Sites/index.html ~/Sites/index.css
Open the current folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets .
Open a specific folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets ~/Sites/mysite
Brackets can be launched from the command line.
Presently it does not accept any other arguments.
Any updates required will be implemented.
Closes #5829

comments.bodyText:
I think that may be a heavily modified version of TinyBasic designed specifically for programming micro controllers. TinyBasic seems to have been written in the 1970s (see this guide from 1976), and the guide that you linked to is from 2009. Wikipedia seems to corroborate the 1970s timeline, and it doesn't refer to any recently updated version of TinyBasic.
In addition to that, the creator of TinyBasic according to Wikipedia is Dennis Allison (from the US), while the creator of the TinyBasic from the guide that you linked is Dr.-Ing. (from Germany). The sample code published on that guide's site also does not seem to match in style to samples provided in this original guide.

comments.bodyText: (Dont worry about the Appveyor failure ; it is marked as not required, because it is failing too frequently atm)

Five things:

assert not timeout should be removed now. That is the main aim of the issue.
It would be incorrect to use warnings.warn here. We should use logging.warning when the event is to be noted, and the end user cannot do anything about it. (Source: Python Docs)
The message ought to be more verbose
A test would be nice. We're merely 6 lines away from reaching 100% branch coverage. (This is what caused my delay ðŸ˜› )
Should be Closes instead of Fixes. #5812 isn't a bug, but rather an issue.
So should I proceed further with the changes or are you submitiing your PR?
@aquatiko I'm not sure about that. More discussion is required, switch to gitter.
@mach64 Could you explain what should be included in the test that you mentioned?

@aquatiko have a look at the files in tests/testing/. You should basically have a test to check that when the verfiy_local_bear function is called with the timeout parameter, a warning is generated. If you get stuck, go through the other files in the folder to see how to properly test strings being printed to stdout and stderr.

In addition, before committing your changes, it is absolutely necessary to run coala on your modified codebase. This will ensure that your changes are fully PEP-8 compliant. (Currently, after every push, you can see that the gitmate bot complains about some inconsistencies. Better to solve them locally, before committing).
EDIT: nevermind, I guess the latest commit is fully compliant. Even then, in the future, I would recommend running coala just before a commit :)

@mach64 Added if timeout: to log warning only when timeout occurs. Wouldn't that comply with the changes requested? i.e in the latest commit

up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

review your PRs faster!

comments.diffHunk:
@@ -127,6 +128,57 @@ def run(self):
 __dir__ = os.path.dirname(__file__)
 
 
+def egg_name_to_requirement(name):
+    name = name.strip()
+    parts = name.split('-')
+
+    # The first part may be v or v0, which would be considered a version
+    # if processed in the following loop.
+    name_parts = [parts[0]]
+    # Pre-releases may contain a '-' and be alpha only, so we must
+    # parse from the second part to find the first version-like part.
+    for part in parts[1:]:
+        version = LooseVersion(part)
+        version = version.version
+        v_prefix = version[0] == 'v'
+        if v_prefix:
+            version = version[1:]
+        if isinstance(version[0], int):
+            break
+        name_parts.append(part)
+
+    version_parts = parts[len(name_parts):]
+
+    if not version_parts:
+        return name
+
+    name = '-'.join(name_parts)
+
+    version = LooseVersion('-'.join(version_parts))
+
+    # Assume that alpha, beta, pre, post & final releases
+    # are in PyPi so setutools can find it.
+    if not any(part == 'dev' for part in version.version):
+        return name + '==' + version
+
+    # For development releases, which will not usually be PyPi,
+    # setuptools will fail with `==` and `~=` as it will look for the
+    # release in PyPi.
+    # Decrement the first non-final version part, which should be in PyPi,
+    # and use version specifier >= so that the installed package from VCS
+    # will have a version acceptable to the requirement.
+    for i, part in enumerate(version.version):
+        if not isinstance(part, int):
+            break
+
+    previous_final_version = version.version[0:i]
+    previous_final_version[i - 1] -= 1
+
+    version = '.'.join(str(part) for part in previous_final_version)
+
+    return name + '>=' + version

likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,75 @@
+Profile Bears
+=============
+
+This document provides an overview of coala's Profiling Interface. The
+Profiling Interface provides an abilities to profile Bear code to optimize its
+performance.
+
+The profiler will start by profiling the run() method of bears because this is
+the part where bear writers will spend time on, as rest of the part like loading
+the files, collecting the settings, etc. are done by coala itself.
+
+.. note::
+
+    Enabliling both profiler and debugger on a bear at a same time will result
+    into error.
+
+Bear writers will have the ability to directly dump the raw profile output
+(binary output) either on current working directory or to a specified directory
+name, which can be further used for examination of profiler stats with the help
+of different modules like ``pstats`` or ``snakeviz``.
+
+``--profile`` or ``profile`` (using coafile) is the main argument to enable
+profiling. It accepts an additional parameter directory name or directory path
+where profiled files will be dumped, if ``True`` is provided profiled files will
+be saved to current working directory. If specified directory does not exists it
+will create one and if path specified is already a file path then it will throw
+``FileExitsError``.

comments.bodyText: I guess all this belongs into the Usage section. It should be maybe stripped as well since you describe already how to enable the profiler below. But the FileExistsError is important, that could go directly below the Usage paragraph, describing how paths are treated.

@@ -0,0 +1,74 @@
+Profile Bears
+=============
+
+This document provides an overview of coala's Profiling Interface. The
+Profiling Interface provides abilities to profile Bear code to optimize its
+performance.
+
+The profiler will start by profiling the run() method of bears because this is
+the part where bear writers will spend time on, as rest of the part like loading
+the files, collecting the settings, etc. are done by coala itself.
+
+.. note::
+
+    Enabling both profiler and debugger on a bear at the same time will result
+    in error.
+
+Bear writers will have the ability to directly dump the raw profile output
+either on current working directory or to a specified directory name, which can
+be further used for examination of profiler stats with the help of different
+modules like ``pstats`` or ``snakeviz``.
+
+Usage
+-----
+
+coala's Profiler accepts an additional parameter, directory name or directory
+path where profiled files will be dumped, if ``True`` is provided profiled
+files will be saved to current working directory. If specified directory does
+not exists it will create one and if path specified is already a file path then
+it will throw ``FileExistsError``.
+
+.. note::
+
+    All bears (even implicit dependency bears) in a section will be profiled.
+    Profiled files will have a name format ``{section.name}_{bear.name}.prof``.
+
+Command Line Interface
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Bear writers can invoke the profiler with the ``--profile`` argument.
+
+- To dump profile files in current working directory:
+
+  .. code:: shell
+
+      $coala -b PEP8Bear,PyUnusedCodeBear -f <filename> --profile
+
+- To dump profile files to a specified directory:
+

+

+

+      files = <filename>
+      profile = True
+
+- To dump profile files to a specified directory:
+

+

+      files = <filename>
+      profile = DirName/Dirpath

+This document provides an overview of coala's Profiling Interface. The

ill avoid the next grammar lesson.
After dumped add a full stop.  Add two carraige returns.
Short simple intros are what people will read.  If the short intro is stuffed into a large paragraph, they will try to avoid it.
Then explain the profile arg options in a new paragraph.  And this usage section should not mention "True" , the title case Python constant, as there are multiple ways to enable profiling, and many do not require the Python keyword True.  Dumb it down.  Use prose.

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText:
what is typed_list(bool)(bear.section['debug_bears'])[0] ?
that is buggy as.  I know what you are trying to do.  You want to hide the ValueError exceptions which could happen.  But it only hides some of them, because that is not what typed_list(bool) is designed to do.
You need to let go of that horrible or you have in the return.  It is forcing you to write more complicated and buggy code.
bool(bear.section['debug_bears']) can raise exceptions.  So, you need to catch them.  We even have a MR related to it at https://gitlab.com/coala/coala-utils/merge_requests/34/diffs .
Then after you have finished checking if it is a bool, then do another check if it is a list of bear names.
And do not use typed_list(str).  bear.section['debug_bears'] is already the appropriate type.  Read the documentation about that type for how to use it correctly.

@@ -67,3 +67,4 @@ exclude_lines =

   pragma ${OS_NAME}: no cover

comments.bodyText:
I've explained on https://gitlab.com/coala/mobans/issues/84 why I think that is unnecessary.
If necessary, we have a check script which verifies that all entry points defined in the yaml have exactly these two lines at end of the file.  That prevents these sequences from being different in multiple entry points, and also ensures they are identical on all repos with entry points.

+from inspect import getmro
+from functools import wraps
+
+
+def typed_filter(type_classes, msg=None):
+    """
+    Used to enforce type of the first argument of a method
+    by its class name as string. Raises NotImplementedError
+    if the type does not match. Primarily used to enforce
+    type of a filter.
+
+    :param type_classes:    list or tuple of acceptable class names
+                            as strings for the first argument of the
+                            method being decorated.
+    :param msg:             Message to pass with NotImplementedError.
+    """
+    if (type(type_classes) not in (tuple, list)):
+        type_classes = (type_classes,)
+
+    def decorator(filter):
+
+        @wraps(filter)
+        def decorated_filter(thing, *args, **kargs):

comments.bodyText:
it was going so well until you mentioned filter here.
the thing you are wrapping has a name, which you are using here.
This decorator is a developer helper ... to catch when they have done the wrong thing.  it shouldnt give pretty names ... the caller needs to detect this and make it user-friendly.
Why should a NotImplementedError say "language_filter filter" .. ?  language_filter is better, and the backtrace is even better, so no need to tidy it up.
To help, create a subclass of NotImplementedError and stuff into it extra attributes to record what went wrong, such as the callee, expected classes, and the incorrect object which was encountered.   Then whoever is catching it can understand what went wrong and create a user-friendly message.
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,42 @@
+from inspect import getmro
+from functools import wraps
+
+
+def typed_filter(type_classes, msg=None):
+    """
+    Used to enforce type of the first argument of a method
+    by its class name as string. Raises NotImplementedError
+    if the type does not match. Primarily used to enforce
+    type of a filter.
+
+    :param type_classes:    list or tuple of acceptable class names
+                            as strings for the first argument of the
+                            method being decorated.
+    :param msg:             Message to pass with NotImplementedError.
+    """
+    if (type(type_classes) not in (tuple, list)):
+        type_classes = (type_classes,)
+
+    def decorator(filter):
+
+        @wraps(filter)
+        def decorated_filter(thing, *args, **kargs):
+            thing_class = thing.__class__
+            all_bases = list(map(lambda klass: klass.__name__,

Removed E133,E242 and E303 from pycodestyle_ignore list.
Fixes #5389
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

comments.bodyText: @jayvdb My PR can't seem to pass this one test.What changes do I need to make?
@jayvdb Please review this.
@jayvdb I have done rebasing.Please review this.

If you see a test failing, check out the detailed logs, try to find the error. You can ask for help on gitter.
For now, I see there's timeout error in your ci (which causes trouble sometimes). It's nothing to do with your PR so don't worry.
@pareksha  I have changed my shortlog message.And,concerning the error,as it is due to timeout,is there anything that I need to do?
This is not rebased.
"Change made as per requirement" is an inappropriate https://coala.io/commit shortlog
"Change in .coalafile" also does not describe what was changed.

ok, the shortlog is good enough.
Next, #5389 does not say it is a bug, so you need the final line to say Closes https://github.com/coala/coala/issues/5389 -- not Fixes https://github.com/coala/coala/issues/5389
Awesome.  Now we let that build, and ping me on gitter for the next step.

issue.title: Add Support for FileProxies
issue.body:
Adds support for FileProxies and analysis of in-memory files.
Known Shortcomings:

Cannot yet work with apply-patch actions.
File Proxies cannot yet work with caching disabled.

+class FileDictFileCache(FileCache, FileDictGenerator):
+    """
+    FileDictFileCache extends a traditional FileCache
+    to support generation of a complete file dict, this
+    lets FileDictFileCache provide access to both file
+    cache and contents of files from disk.
+    """
+
+    def __init__(self, *args, **kargs):
+        """
+        This directly initializes the associated FileCache.
+        """
+        super().__init__(*args, **kargs)
+
+    def get_file_dict(self, filename_list, allow_raw_files=False):
+        """
+        Returns a file dictionary mapping from filename to lines of
+        file. Uses coalib.processes.Processing.get_file_dict().
+
+        :param filename_list:   List of filenames as strings to build
+                                the file dict.
+        :param allow_raw_files: Indicates if the file could also be
+                                read as a binary.
+        :return:                Reads the content of each file into
+                                dictionary with filenames as keys.
+        """
+        return get_file_dict(filename_list,
+                             allow_raw_files=allow_raw_files)
+
+
+class ProxyMapFileCache(FileCache, FileDictGenerator):
+    """
+    ProxyMapFileCache is a FileCache that also provides
+    methods to produce a file dict from a FileProxyMap.
+
+    >>> import logging
+    >>> import tempfile
+    >>> import copy, time
+    >>> logging.getLogger().setLevel(logging.CRITICAL)
+
+    >>> file = tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(delete=False)
+    >>> file.write(b'coala')
+    5
+    >>> file.close()
+
+    A new instance of ProxyMapFileCache can be instantited:
+
+    >>> proxycache = ProxyMapFileCache(None, "test")
+
+    Before any action on the associated proxy map is carried
+    out, the proxymap needs to be initialized/set using:
+
+    >>> proxymap = FileProxyMap()
+    >>> proxycache.set_proxymap(proxymap)
+
+    A file dict can now be build using the underlying proxy
+    map using:
+
+    >>> proxy = FileProxy.from_file(file.name, None)
+    >>> proxymap.add(proxy)
+    True
+
+    >>> file_dict = proxycache.get_file_dict([file.name])
+    >>> file_dict[file.name]
+    ('coala',)
+    """
+
+    def __init__(self, *args, **kargs):
+        """
+        This directly initializes the associated FileCache.
+        """
+        super().__init__(*args, **kargs)
+        self.__proxymap = None
+
+    @enforce_signature
+    def set_proxymap(self, fileproxy_map: FileProxyMap):
+        """
+        Used to assign a ProxyMap, this is separate from
+        the instance initialization method to keep the
+        concerns separate.
+
+        :param fileproxy_map:   FileProxyMap instance to build
+                                the file dict from.
+        """
+        self.__proxymap = fileproxy_map
+
+    def get_file_dict(self, filename_list, allow_raw_files=False):
+        """
+        Builds a file dictionary from filename to lines of the file
+        from an associated FileProxyMap.
+
+        :param filename_list:   List of files to get the contents of.
+        :param allow_raw_files: Allow the usage of raw files (non text files),
+                                disabled by default
+        :return:                Reads the content of each file into dictionary
+                                with filenames as keys.
+        """
+        if self.__proxymap is None:
+            raise ValueError('set_proxymap() should be called to set proxymap'
+                             'of ProxyMapFileCache instance')
+
+        file_dict = {}
+        for filename in filename_list:
+            try:
+                # Keep the binary mode turned off to maintain compatibility
+                # with FileDictFileCache.get_file_dict().
+                # filename is assumed to be normcased.
+                proxy = self.__proxymap.resolve(filename,
+                                                hard_sync=True,
+                                                binary=False)
+
+                file_lines = proxy.lines()
+                file_dict[filename] = tuple(file_lines)
+            except UnicodeDecodeError:
+                if allow_raw_files:
+                    file_dict[filename] = None
+                    continue
+
+                logging.warning("Failed to read file '{}'. It seems to contain "
+                                'non-unicode characters. Leaving it out.'
+                                .format(filename))
+
+            except (OSError, FileNameError) as exception:
+                log_exception("Failed to read file '{}' because of an unknown "
+                              'error. Leaving it out.'.format(filename),
+                              exception,
+                              log_level=LOG_LEVEL.WARNING)
+
+        logging.debug('Files that will be checked:\n' +

+        self.__proxymap = fileproxy_map
+
+    def get_file_dict(self, filename_list, allow_raw_files=False):
+        """
+        Builds a file dictionary from filename to lines of the file
+        from an associated FileProxyMap.
+
+        :param filename_list:   List of files to get the contents of.
+        :param allow_raw_files: Allow the usage of raw files (non text files),
+                                disabled by default
+        :return:                Reads the content of each file into dictionary
+                                with filenames as keys.
+        """
+        if self.__proxymap is None:
+            raise ValueError('set_proxymap() should be called to set proxymap'
+                             'of ProxyMapFileCache instance')
+
+        file_dict = {}
+        for filename in filename_list:
+            try:
+                # Keep the binary mode turned off to maintain compatibility
+                # with FileDictFileCache.get_file_dict().
+                # filename is assumed to be normcased.
+                proxy = self.__proxymap.resolve(filename,
+                                                hard_sync=True,
+                                                binary=False)
+
+                file_lines = proxy.lines()
+                file_dict[filename] = tuple(file_lines)
+            except UnicodeDecodeError:
+                if allow_raw_files:
+                    file_dict[filename] = None
+                    continue
+
+                logging.warning("Failed to read file '{}'. It seems to contain "
+                                'non-unicode characters. Leaving it out.'
+                                .format(filename))
+
+            except (OSError, FileNameError) as exception:
+                log_exception("Failed to read file '{}' because of an unknown "
+                              'error. Leaving it out.'.format(filename),
+                              exception,
+                              log_level=LOG_LEVEL.WARNING)
+
+        logging.debug('Files that will be checked:\n' +

+
+class ProxyMapFileCache(FileCache, FileDictGenerator):
+    """
+    ProxyMapFileCache is a FileCache that also provides
+    methods to produce a file dict from a FileProxyMap.
+
+    >>> import logging

+    >>> import copy, time

+
+    >>> file = tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(delete=False)
+    >>> file.write(b'coala')
+    5
+    >>> file.close()
+
+    A new instance of ProxyMapFileCache can be instantited:
+
+    >>> proxycache = ProxyMapFileCache(None, "test")
+
+    Before any action on the associated proxy map is carried

+    >>> proxymap = FileProxyMap()

+

comments.bodyText:
Ok, so my understanding is you have already performed partial conversion to a dict based filter structure. A few remarks here:

Use OrderedDicts, filtering order is important here.
Use tuples for holding args, not lists.
Do not partially convert the filters, you should rather have all the filter args as tuples. {'language': ('c', 'java'), 'can_fix': ('syntax',), 'section_tags': ('save',)} otherwise it will force all the other unrelated methods to handle this case.

issue.title: LocalBearTestHelper: Decommission timeout
issue.body:
LocalBearTestHelper had an undeclared dependency on pytest-timeout
so it would not work unless the user had install pytest-timeout.
None of our bear test suites use this timeout argument, as the
timeout set in their repo configuration is sufficient.
Fixes #5508

issue.title: Release notes now published at api docs
issue.body:
Release Notes are now published at api docs.
I was not familiar with reStructuredText.
I was initially trying to add Release Notes in
.. toctree::
   :caption: Home
   :hidden:

   Welcome <self>
   Homepage <http://coala.io/#/home>
   Release Notes <release_notes>
   Code of Conduct <http://coala.io/coc>
but it was giving out every title in this toctree, which is not suitable so I shifted Release Notes to it's own toctree.
Also to commit release_notes.rst i have to exclude it from .gitignore.
Closes: #5724

comments.bodyText: I followed the guidelines and made commits accordingly. When I ran coala locally I've got a warning but no errors.
You have to ensure all tests pass locally before you push it to github. This includes not having any warnings thrown by pytest. Follow this to properly test your changes.
The CI builds are failing because your local repo is out of sync with master. You'll have to rebase first.

Nice work with the testing. The commit message still seems a bit out of place. How about __init__.py: Arrange imports alphabetically? It is short and crisp, and still conveys the relevant information about the commit.
I agree with @mach64, see if you can add language word in the commit msg too, something like __init__: Arrange lang imports alphabetically, as __init__ doesn't tell much about the file.
I think python 3.4 test generally fails. (Though you can confirm with others too)
Do you mean which lines I shouldn't move? There are only two .Language imports and rest are .definition imports
Yeah.Do not move the .Language imports.You should keep the imports from two different files i.e. from Language and definitions SEPARATED so as to promote better readability of the code.
i've already tried it. using lexicographically exceeding char limit
Remove lang part from commit message and add lexico in it and then cover it in shortlog of the message.
Removing lang and replacing lexico caused me pytest error @Monal5031

@Mah1ndra Read my message again. I asked to remove lang part and replace alpha with lexicographically. and since we are removing lang from head you will have to explain it in shortlog.
Does that make it clear?
And from what I can see it is due to something else the tests are failing, (how would a commit message make your tests fail? ðŸ˜• )
i don't know just after changing the commit msg pystest error occured

I read the logs for this commit as well, the ci/circleci: python-3.4 seems to have failed for reasons other than the changes in this PR but please wait for review from another member just to be sure! ðŸ˜„
Thank you for your review @atb00ker ðŸ˜ƒ

@atb00ker is correct.
Tests is passing in Travis CI and appveyor for Py3.4.4 and failing in CircleCI.

First of all as per coala guidelines of handling pull request there is only one commit per pull request ,so you should squash all the commits into single commit .
secondly try to understand gitmate changes ,your commit message is not as per gitmate bot.
refer this https://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Writing_Good_Commits.html
and http://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Git_Basics.html

issue.title: Undefined name: import sys

issue.title: Do not error hard because a dependency of a bear has been updated
issue.body:
Currently, upon a simple load of bears, we implicitly check every single dependency to see if it's exactly as any given bear hard pins to antequated versions and fail hard if you are even slightly off. I don't see a reason this should be the case as this is Python; it's not coala's concern whether I've installed a later isort version than it expects, especially not at runtime.
This simple fix merely resolves each entrypoint instead, which is really what we're trying to do anyway.

issue.title: [WIP] Make the README a kinder place by removing/replacing the John Woods quote.
issue.body:
Hey folks ðŸ‘‹
This PR is to discuss the removal of the John Woods quote from the README. I believe that quote is a product of its time (1991), and that Coala can do better to be a welcoming project.
We should write maintainable code because we have respect for our peers and colleagues who will read and work with it, not because of threat of death. The quote is also unnecessarily gendered.
Apologies also for the drive-by PR ðŸ™‡  For some additional context, I became aware of this quote because I work with a lot of software development students, and saw a large number were contributors to Coala. Coala is doing an amazing job of being accessible to students and upcoming software developers, but this also makes it important to ensure that students who work on this project are being taught respect for their fellow humans ðŸ’–
I've added [WIP] as currently this commit removes the quote entirely. It may be more suitable to find an alternative to fill that space and act as the one-line pitch. If anyone has suggestions, please feel free to add them!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. No changes to code - only to the README

comments.bodyText:
So I'm not sure whether this PR will get merged or not, only the maintainers can tell us (cc @jayvdb @Makman2  ) but I would like to start suggesting alternatives for the quote that might replace the current one.
One of my favorite quotes is the Linus Law and I think this goes well with coala since our community is so much focussed on reviews and we try to turn newcomers into reviewers early on in their open source careers.

"given enough eyeballs, all bugs are shallow"

Or this Martin Fowler quote

â€œIâ€™m not a great programmer; Iâ€™m just a good programmer with great habits.â€

seems like an overkill of moral behaviour in the context of inability to take a joke. ðŸ¤¨
When we say "Do or die" are we imparting death upon someone or disrespecting in any way?

@ishanSrt Itâ€™s not about not taking a joke, itâ€™s about good copy writing. Jokes are great! But itâ€™s a readme: it should communicate about the project. I just believe that space could be better utilised to communicate about the project, than telling an old joke.
But Iâ€™m not gonna fight for the point - it was a good faith suggestion by someone who is not a contributor to this project, take it or leave it ðŸ’–
This was something I never thought about ðŸ¤” even I started thinking why that quote is there but yeah it can have a better replacement.

If you don't mind, it would be better if you could remove [WIP] from your title and do a force repush, so that gitmate-bot would label this pull request as process/pending review. Otherwise people would skip this pull request. c.f. http://coala.io/review

I am thinking that it would be better if @joenash could just raise an issue about this and close this PR as it is still not clear whether we will be removing this quote or replacing this.
Better to copy paste this to an issue thread and continue the conversation. This could be a good newcomer's issue
Migrated to #5792
Sorry folks, only just saw the suggestions. Thank you!

comments.bodyText:
IMHO The above approach wouldn't work because len(section.contents) would never be zero.
The reason being section.contents is never empty. Even if your .coafile is something like below where your [cli] section is not present. It would help you to know that the [ cli ] section is generated automatically by Cliparser.py when you supply the arguments to coala. This section gets saved to your .coafile when you supply --save option.
[python]
files = admin.py
bears = SpaceConsistencyBear, QuotesBear
language = Python
preferred_quotation = '

default_actions = **: ApplyPatchAction

When i tried to debug it, section.contents always returns a Ordered dict of length 1 when the contents in the [ cli ] section is empty. I tried to print the value of section.contents when the [ cli ] section is empty. It's something like:-
OrderedDict([('comment0', <Setting object(key='comment0', value='', origin='/home/theprophet/git/thepursuit/oth/.coafile', from_cli=False, to_append=False) at 0x7f5ed01aa1d0>)])


From the above result I can positively say that section always maintains elements in its dictionary even when a section is empty.This is done so that the core of coala can properly identify it.
That's the reason, you checking if len(section.contents) == 0 will not work.Since this doesn't work your if condition fails and the message Executing Section CLI will always prompt up.
I guess you need to change your approach.
P.S:- Please test your changes locally before creating a PR. This will save yours and the reviewers time :)

-            print_section_beginning(section)
+            if not (section.name == 'cli' and len(section.contents) == 0):

In any case, I guess this issue has two parts:-


Print Executing Section CLI only when the coala is provided with options. eg:-
coala --file = avenger.py --bears SpaceConsistencyBear, print the message Executing Section CLI when you execute this. But do not print it when you do the same operation using a .coafile.
Executing section cli gets printed even when we supply no arguments to coala.
If there was no [ cli ] section in the .coafile then this could be solved by a very small change in your present solution.


Check if there is a section named [ cli ] in the .coafile and check if its contents are empty (Do not use section.contents ðŸ˜…). If so do not print the message. If it isn't empty then print it. But then again, this is a kinda broader issue.

comments.bodyText: Hello, @richardson-souza before sending the pr please check whether the code is following PEP8 guidelines or not,  you can have an IDE or an editor offering PEP8 checks to do the same. Secondly, you need to change the commit message as it is not following the expected style see here https://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Writing_Good_Commits.html  and one more thing please tick mark the checkbox in your pr message description

Awesome.  Most people fail when trying to re-open a PR.
Now, the next step in fixing your PR is to squash your two commits into one commit.
There are many ways to squash commits, and we have some suggestions at https://coala.io/git
Here is one approach which should work quite well for your current situation.
$ git checkout richardson
$ git reset --soft HEAD~1  # discard the top commit, but keep the changes 
$ git add coalib/coala_main.py  # submit this to be added
$ git commit --amend  # put the additional changes into the most recent commit
# an editor will open with the existing commit message
Check you have one commit only, and it contains what you wish to submit to this PR.
$ git log
$ git show

If there is only one commit by you, and it is correct, you can push that to this PR.
The next step is to improve your commit message.
Again, see https://coala.io/commit and https://coala.io/git for tips, or ask for help on https://coala.io/chat .

What issue are you intending to solve? Please mention that in your opening comment #5781 (comment)
Also please learn git basics first before do further changes. This PR is getting messy.
